content: Please continue in https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1454255
creator: wsmwk

content: Do you have Norton Password Manager affecting TB passwords? Normally, a password can be changed by removing it from Saved Passwords, restarting TB, entering the new password in the prompt and checking the box to have it stored in Saved Passwords. This is for accounts with 'normal password' authentication, and is a bit different with other types of authentication. If there are no entries in Saved Passwords, it often points to an external app that is managing passwords.
creator: sfhowes

content: Thanks, sfhowes. I do not have Norton Password Manager installed, and have (temporarily) removed Norton 360. I do use Bitwarden as a password manager, but it is set up more as a reference rather than to autofill or manage passwords. There are no passwords in "Saved Passwords", and when I get the password entry prompt at login, there is no box to choose to save the password. I wonder if this is a result of an older preference setting? I used Seamonkey for years and moved to Thunderbird a few years ago.
creator: linda.snider

content:
If you've used the same profile over several versions of TB, there might be some obsolete file that is affecting the passwords. I recall there was an issue with secmod.db.

If you can't find the source of the problem, try adding an IMAP account to a new profile and see if it works correctly. Help/Troubleshooting Info, about:profiles, to create and manage profiles. The current profile is unaffected, and if the new one works, data can be transferred from the old to the new.

Edizione Windows 11 Pro Versione 23H2 Data installazione: ‎30.‎01.‎2024 Build sistema operativo 22631.3880 Esperienza Windows Feature Experience Pack 1000.22700.1020.0

creator: olivio.beloedil

content:
I problemi che stai segnalando dipendono quasi sempre da problemi con il file system. Oltre alla questione dei diritti (a proposito su che percorso è il profilo di Thunderbird? perché dalle immagini non è visibile) può essere causato da carenza di spazio sul disco e da archivi che hanno raggiunto una dimensione eccessiva (ad esempio superiore ai 4 GB). Altra possibile causa è un software di sicurezza "troppo zelante" che tiene bloccato uno o più file di Thunderbird impedendo al programma di accedervi in scrittura. In ultima ipotesi potrebbe esserci anche un problema di integrità del disco/drive che potresti verificare con un programma di diagnostica SMART.

In generale comunque è difficile venirne a capo, per specie se stai usando IMAP forse si fa prima a ripartire da un profilo pulito -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/utilizzare-piu-profili

Se vuoi sentire altre opinioni prova a scrivere anche sul forum di Mozilla Italia -> https://forum.mozillaitalia.org/index.php

content: I don't think Thunderbird is your problem, it's your inventory of old messages that require storage space. IMAP accounts never 'let go' of the messages. To save your disc space, you might consider setting up a cloud storage account or buy external media and save there.

content: An app password is one that your email provider gives you for use when using an email client. That is, the password you use online for the account will not work on Thunderbird or any other email client. Each email provider may have unique process in doing this.
creator: davidsk

content: That setting you referred to only affects folders you create AFTER making the change. This article specifies exactly how to do it. As written, it focuses on using table view, but the steps work. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/message-threading-thunderbird
creator: davidsk

content: Thunderbird has filters for unread messagesl and for predefined spam or other uses. I suggest first using fiters to move selected messages to a tempirary folder to ensure you don't delete important messages
